channel.title: Merged Defense / NATO / SpaceWar Feed
channel.description: Aggregated RSS feed from NATO, DefenseOne, and SpaceWar

item.title: Poland seeks better counter-drone tech after Russian incursion
item.description: Warsaw’s foreign minister also hopes the U.S. will send more troops to train with its military.

item.title: Silicon Valley in St. Louis?
item.description: With the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency as its north star, a non-profit is working to get defense tech to put down roots in the Midwest.

item.title: Hegseth, Vought actions heighten fears about inspector-general independence
item.description: Good-government groups and lawmakers from both parties say Trump-administration moves will chill whistleblowing and watchdog offices.

item.title: The D Brief: War on leaks; IGs, targeted; Guard-deployment sitrep; The next geoint hub?; And a bit more.
Elon Musk’s SpaceX took money directly from Chinese investors, company insider testifies
item.description: The newly unsealed testimony marks the first time direct Chinese investment in the company has been disclosed, raising new questions about foreign stakes in one of America’s most important military contractors.

item.title: 'Shadow economies' are growing. Military planners and operators must take them into account
item.description: Black markets prolong wars, defang sanctions, fray alliances, and help rogue governments and groups survive and thrive.

item.title: Inside Europe's crash effort to create a 'drone wall'
item.description: More sensors, more maneuverable, less expensive: How the Ukraine war is shaping the future of drone air defense.

item.title: The D Brief: Trump declares war on cartels; Feds storm Chicago apartments; Europe’s ‘drone wall’; Shadow economies; And a bit more.
Shutdown poised to drag into next week as layoff threat looms
item.description: Senate once again fails to approve spending bill and the two sides remain far divided.

item.title: NGA wants to put its idle PCs to work
item.description: GDIT is networking the agency’s St. Louis workstations to crunch geospatial data even when analysts aren’t around.

item.title: The D Brief: Guard deployments on hold; 4th speedboat bombed; Russia strikes Lviv; China’s black-market oil; And a bit more.
Venezuela, US edge toward war footing—but the White House may blink first
item.description: The Trump administration is increasing the pressure, but domestic concerns, international risks may hold it back.

item.title: Hamas has run out of options
item.description: The group's survival now rests on accepting Trump’s plan and political reform.

item.title: More employees set to receive furlough notices as shutdown drags on
item.description: DOD has not said how long nonexempt civilian employees might be kept working.

item.title: Flood of questions leads Missile Defense Agency to push Golden Dome deadline one week
item.description: Pitches for a slice of MDA’s 10-year, up-to-$151 billion contract vehicle are now due Oct. 16.

item.title: OMB quietly deletes reference to law requiring back pay to furloughed feds
item.description: A White House FAQ now says restitution is only guaranteed to excepted employees forced to work without pay.

item.title: The D Brief: Troops to Chicago; Trump’s partisan speech to sailors; F/A-XX OK?; MDA’s big Golden Dome vehicle; And a bit more.
Denied in July, DHS intelligence office resumes efforts to shed staff
item.description: After stakeholders scuttled dramatic cuts, the Office of Intelligence and Analysis is quietly offering buyouts instead.

item.title: Skeptical senators grill White House pick to lead Indo-Pacific policy
item.description: The nominee to be assistant defense secretary for Indo-Pacific security affairs, backed the president's push for Taiwan to spend more.

item.title: Federal shutdown deals blow to already-hobbled cybersecurity agency
item.description: Two-thirds of the staff at the nation’s cybersecurity agency are sidelined, opening opportunities for malicious hackers.

item.title: The D Brief: Senators doubt Asia policy; Jail Illinois leaders, says POTUS; Civil-military ‘crisis’; DHS cuts intel staff; And a bit more.
It’s time to return Turkey to the F-35 fold, even if we have to get creative
item.description: It's a sticking point that is blocking deeper US-NATO-Turkish defense cooperation.

item.title: Legal experts fear Trump admin is ignoring JAGs on cartel strikes, Guard deployments
item.description: A former military lawyer and a former judge encouraged commanders to stand up to unlawful orders.

item.title: Lawmakers call for more defense biotech research as China pursues breakthroughs
item.description: Shelf-stable blood, biological camouflage, and biosensors are just some of the potential innovations.

item.title: ‘Stop trying to control every step’ of shipbuilding, senator tells Navy
item.description: Focus less on requirements and more on outcomes, says Montana’s Sheehy, and the entire Pentagon might get on board.

item.title: Next generation interceptor from Raytheon takes aim at drone warfare
item.description:
Los Angeles CA (SPX) Oct 09, 2025
Raytheon, an RTX business, has revealed a prototype for its Next Generation Short Range Interceptor (NGSRI), a system designed to replace the combat-proven Stinger missile and meet the growing threat posed by drones and advanced airborne systems. Built with extensive input from soldiers and Marines, the new interceptor promises to fly both faster and farther, while integrating next-level sensing

item.title: Top UK prosecutor blames government for dropped China spy case
item.description:
London (AFP) Oct 8, 2025
A high-profile case involving two men accused of spying for China was dropped because the UK government failed to provide evidence Beijing was a security threat, the chief prosecutor has said. Prosecutors have come under fire from lawmakers and government officials after charges against two men, including a former parliamentary researcher, were dismissed last month. But Director of Publi

item.title: Germany joins EU nations with plans to shoot down unknown drones
item.description:
Washington DC (UPI) Oct 8, 2025
Federal authorities in Germany were granted permission to shoot down drones following a series of recent sightings of unknown drones spotted near Munich. The German government's cabinet on Wednesday signed-off on the new reform package that now awaits approval of the Bundestag, the country's parliament. The move came after drones were seen at Munich Airport last week, which led t

item.title: Guyana strengthens territorial defense with French military support
item.description:
Washington DC (UPI) Oct 8, 2025
During the opening ceremony of the French Embassy in Guyana, President Irfaan Ali said his country was ready to accept the France's offer of technological assistance - including land and maritime radar systems - to monitor Venezuela's movements amid pressure over the Essequibo region. At the event Saturday, Ali confirmed that Guyana and France are cooperating on defense and security a

item.title: German police to get power to shoot down drones: minister
item.description:
Berlin (AFP) Oct 8, 2025
German federal police will soon be allowed to shoot down unmanned aerial vehicles, Interior Minister Alexander Dobrindt said Wednesday, after a spate of drone sightings believed to be Russian efforts to spy and intimidate. Unveiling a draft law, Dobrindt said police would be authorised "to take state-of-the-art technical action against drone threats, for example with electromagnetic pulses,

item.title: Space Systems Command adds second Blue Origin deal to boost vehicle processing at Cape Canaveral
item.description:
El Segundo CA (SPX) Oct 09, 2025
Space Systems Command is expanding its space vehicle processing capacity at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station by 2028, awarding Blue Origin a $78.25 million contract. The award is the second National Security Space Launch Space Vehicle Processing Commercial Solutions Opening contract aimed at strengthening responsive and resilient launch operations. "This second CSO award reflects our con

item.title: Iran dismissees Israel's missile concern as 'made-up threat'
item.description:
Tehran (AFP) Oct 7, 2025
Iran on Tuesday dismissed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's warnings over its missile programme as fabricated, after he alleged the Islamic republic was developing rockets capable of reaching US cities. In an interview with US podcaster Ben Shapiro released on Monday, Netanyahu said: "Iran is developing now... intercontinental ballistic missiles for 8,000 kilometre range". "Wha

item.title: Iran summons EU envoys over bloc's 'interventionist' stance
item.description:
Tehran (AFP) Oct 8, 2025
Iran summoned envoys from European Union member states to protest the bloc's "interventionist" statements on contested islands in the Strait of Hormuz as well as the Islamic republic's nuclear programme, local media reported Wednesday. Iran considers the islands of Greater Tunb, Lesser Tunb and Abu Musa, all near the strategic Strait of Hormuz in the Gulf, as part of its sovereign territory.

item.title: North Korea expected to stage military parade as party turns 80
item.description:
Seoul (AFP) Oct 9, 2025
North Korea is set to host top officials from China and Russia to mark 80 years under the ruling Workers' Party, a celebration that is expected to feature a massive military parade showcasing its latest advanced weaponry. Planning for the spectacle, which could begin as early as Thursday, has been shrouded in secrecy, with South Korea's military saying the North may stage the parade at nigh

item.title: Grenade attack in western Iran kills two IRGC members: local media
item.description:
Tehran (AFP) Oct 7, 2025
A grenade attack in western Iran, blamed on militants, killed two members of the country's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC), including a cleric, local media reported Tuesday. The assault, late on Monday, targeted a building belonging to pro-government paramilitary forces near the city of Sarvabad in the western province of Kurdistan and left three other members of the guard corps wou

item.title: Spanish parliament approves Israel arms embargo
item.description:
Madrid (AFP) Oct 8, 2025
Spanish lawmakers on Wednesday approved the enshrinement in law of an arms embargo on Israel that Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez introduced to end what he called "the genocide in Gaza". Parliament backed by 178 votes to 169 the decree announced in September by Sanchez, one of the most virulent critics among world leaders of Israel's devastating two-year-old war in the Palestinian territory.

item.title: US report says European giant, others sell to Chinese military-linked companies
item.description:
Washington (AFP) Oct 7, 2025
A US Congressional committee report released Tuesday said that five major semiconductor equipment manufacturers, including European giant ASML, sold $38 billion worth of critical technology to China in 2024, including to companies flagged as US national security threats. The House Select Committee on the Strategic Competition between the United States and the Chinese Communist Party found th

item.title: Trump unlikely to win Nobel Peace Prize, but who will?
item.description:
Oslo (AFP) Oct 8, 2025
When it comes to this year's Nobel Peace Prize, one thing is almost certain: US President Donald Trump will not win, no matter how much he wants it. But who will? The Norwegian Nobel Committee in Oslo will bring the suspense to an end when it announces the winner Friday at 11:00 am (0900 GMT). The backdrop is bleak: the number of armed conflicts worldwide involving at least one state has

item.title: Russia says missile strike kills three in Belgorod region: governor
item.description:
Moscow (AFP) Oct 8, 2025
A missile strike killed three people in a village in Russia's Belgorod region bordering Ukraine on Wednesday, the local governor said. "The village of Maslova Pristan in the Shebekinsky District was hit by a missile strike. According to preliminary data, three people were killed and one was wounded," governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said on Telegram, adding that some people could still be trapped

item.title: EU 'must respond' to Russia's 'hybrid warfare': von der Leyen
item.description:
Strasbourg, France Oct 8, 2025
EU chief Ursula von der Leyen on Wednesday said Europe must ramp up its defences to deter Russia's "hybrid warfare", after a catalogue of air incursions, cyber attacks and damage to undersea cables. "These incidents are calculated to linger in the twilight of deniability. This is not random harassment. It is a coherent and escalating campaign," the European Commission head said in a speech t
